a tool like Zulip which intends for people to read it later (unlike online chat, which is intended to be real-time)

See, I don't see that difference in Zulip and Slack. I believe that they are both intended to be used in real-time like chat. The difference is that some people want to go back and see what they missed in the real-time discussion and to read several days of the real time discussion (regardless of whether that is the intention or not). I think that some of our users like Zulip, because if you choose to do that, it's much easier to catch up. But, I think the tool is intended to be used the same way. It just has different tools.

But, I don't think the intention is for the tool to be used any differently. I still treat Zulip as a real-time chat tool. But a real-time chat tool that is easier to view the history, if you choose.

@Tuhin we have only recently changed our chat platform, so we cannot simply switch the entire community over again. The main reason we witched from Gitter to Zulip was that the community was getting bigger, and we needed a chat system that supported channels/threads, in order to better handle the increased activity. ...IF we are to change again, there will need to be good reasons. ...here's what I would do if I were you:

  • please open an issue in https://github.com/backdrop-ops/backdropcms.org/issues
  • list the problems with Zulip
  • list the things that discord does better

  • ask for feedback and support for the switch from other Backdrop community members
    ...while at it, please go through the list of features we need, and make sure that Discord does all of these:

  • discussion threads/topics

  • automatic issue linking from GitHub
  • API to support sending notifications from GitHub and our forum to it
  • chatbot support

That's what @Tuhin suggested., but we need to be cautious! ...we can't be asking the community to be moving from one chat platform to another every now and then. If we are to change the chat software we use yet again, there have to be specific problems that we are trying to address, and we need to make sure that if/when we change, we don't lose any functionality that the community needs.

...I know that some people expressed the opinion that Zulip is hard to use/understand (@jenlampton is one such person) ...it needs some getting used to. If we decide that the UX issues are preventing community members from participating, and if Discord or any other software that meets our criteria solves that, then we MAY decide to switch again.

I hate to start a new Zulip topic

Lot's of people seem to have this concern. It surprises me a bit. I don't think at all about starting a new topic. It seems that topic titles give users a sense of structure and durability that I don't see and causes this concern about keeping things organized.

For me Zulip is still a "chat" application and while topics are helpful, they are still pretty casual/informal. I don't think anyone should ever worry about starting a new topic or spend much time looking for an existing one. If one exists, that fine and great, but if not (or if you don't find one quickly) then create a new one.

Just my opinion.
Good to know; I certainly didn't realize that. In the future I'll still look for topics, but won't spend as much time looking as I have been.
Yeah, I wouldn't worry too much. At least the topic has autocomplete so that is helpful
